fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G : {\mathcal{D}} \to {\mathcal{C}} be a functor with a left adjoint F. M = G \mathbin{\circ} F is the corresponding monad on {\mathcal{C}}. This gives a comparison functor K : {\mathcal{A}} \to {\mathcal{C}}^M.

fr:ol.fr:li: If {\mathcal{D}} has all coequalizers (we can weaken this to reflexive coequalizers), then K has a left adjoint.
If moreover G preserves these reflexive coequalizers, the unit {\textrm{Id}} \to K \mathbin{\circ} L is an isomorphism.
Finally, if G reflects isomorphisms, then the counit L \mathbin{\circ} K \to {\textrm{Id}} is also an isomorphism, making G monadic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the final point, we would like the coequalizer of FG\epsilon, \epsilon : FGFGX \rightrightarrows FGX to be isomorphic to X. If we apply G to the diagram, we get an isomorphism to GX by the previous point. So if G reflects isomorphisms, we’re done.

A reflexive pair is the categorical translation of a reflexive relation. It is defined as a pair of arrows \partial_0, \partial_1 : X \rightrightarrows Y with a common section r : Y \to X, i.e. an arrow r such that \partial_0 \mathbin{\circ} r = \partial_1 \mathbin{\circ} r = {\textrm{id}}_Y. A coequalizer of a reflexive pair is called a reflexive coequalizer.
Given a pair of adjoint functors F \dashv G, G is monadic if the corresponding comparison functor to {\mathcal{C}}^{G \mathbin{\circ} F} is an equivalence in the bicategory of decompositions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given an adjunction F \dashv G with the corresponding monad G \mathbin{\circ} F, the comparison functor is defined as sending X to GFGX \to GX, given by the counit FGX \to X.
Let G : {\mathcal{D}} \to {\mathcal{C}} be a functor with a left adjoint F. G is monadic iff G creates coequalizers whose image under G is split.
For necessity, using , we only need to verify that a monad M preserves the relevant coequalizers, which is true since they are absolute.

For sufficiency, we observe the proof of . Notice that the coequalizers involved are of the form F\alpha, \epsilon : FGFA \rightrightarrows FA. The images of these under G are indeed split by \eta : GFA \to GFGFA and \eta : A \to GFA. Therefore we just have to show G reflects isomorphisms. Given an isomorphism Gf : GA \cong GB, we have a split coequalizer GA \rightrightarrows GB \to GA where the two maps on the left are Gf, and the map on the right is its inverse. This creates a map g : B \to A which is the coequalizer of f with itself. So this map must be an isomorphism. We then consider the coequalizer GB \rightrightarrows GA \to GB, where the two maps on the left are Gg and the map on the right is Gf. Since G reflects this limit, f must also be an isomorphism.
